You can get fairly high grades of "precision" from injection molds, so there's really nothing stopping Casino-grade dice being in any size or shape beyond cost and demand.

Some casino dice are cut from extruded rectangular rods, and the polishing process further refines them, all the way to ridiculous and entirely unnecessary levels of tolerance, something to the order of .025mm or lower. However, most "casino" dice are nowhere near that, and have tolerances around just .3mm.

Dice that come out of a quality mold can already be in the .1mm range. That's actually considered rather low, but it surpasses the bottom level of "Casino" standard. I wouldn't be surprised if GameScience dice were around that, and ordinary Chessex dice are probably the same before they go into the tumbler. Expensive, high pressure injection molding can actually reach tolerances of .025mm without any later machining required, but I doubt anyone sells dice made in such a fashion because it would be stupidly expensive for something that would largely be imperceptible.

So, essentially, untumbled dice could be considered to fall into lower end of what's considered "Casino Dice", even though they're not quite at the same level as the highest degrees of casino dice. But, all of these are unnecessary, because even tumbled dice are more than just "good enough" for gaming purposes, they're virtually indistinguishable unless you spend several days nonstop rolling, and even then the degree of variance would require charting before it was perceptible.

Hu Tao is a funeral parlor director, and her Pyro magic has motifs of cremation and "The candle that burns twice as bright burns half as long"; she is a damage-dealer who gains benefits from being very close to death.

Just as two characters who share the same element can be differentiated by their non-elemental themes (e.g. astrology, death), so too can two characters who share the same non-elemental theme be differentiated by their discrete elements.
